questions.question_text: A technician is setting up a Windows 10 laptop as a kiosk at a retail store. Which of the following account types would the technician MOST likely use to configure the machine?

discussion.content: to configure the kiosk you need local admin!!!!
This is ENTIRELY up to corporate policy. Generally speaking, you don't use local accounts for anything in a lot of organizations.

comments.content: true, but out of the list you definitely don't want it to join the domain so out of the other 2 it's the one without admin privileges

discussion.content: This is just stupid...in a kiosk you won't use a standard nor a admin account, but a guest. Is literally created for this purpose.
Why not C

comments.content: this is probably because it's being used as a kiosk in a public setting, you would want to give it the least amount of privileges as possible
It doesn't specify the account will be in use, rather which account you are using to set up the kiosk machine.
you don't want users to be local admins

discussion.content: Why not Local administrative account?
I meant DNS (not UNC)...
Can someone explain why the answer is UNC?

questions.question_text:
A technician is configuring a student laptop, and the network administrator requires it to be statically configured. The technician successfully pings the servers by
IP but cannot ping by UNC. Which of the following is MOST likely the issue?

discussion.content: why not C?

comments.content: unlikely to fix anything as beeps usually indicate a hardware related problem

questions.question_text: Ann, an end user, hears multiple beeps each time she attempts to start her workstation, but the computer does not boot successfully. The workstation was recently serviced for a separate issue. Which of the following will MOST likely resolve the current issue with the shortest amount of downtime?

comments.content: I was thinking the same, however i think using the FN key is really a second step for if, for whatever reason, after configuring display settings the display still doesn't show up.
The correct answer is C, they didn’t say toggle the displays... if they said toggle you’ll need to use the FN keys.
That is AFTER you have connected the relevant cables, though.

The question specifically asks what you do AFTER the cables are connected. examprepper is correct, any CompTIA training material i've read mentions Fn keys first when it talks about multiple monitor set ups. Not saying you can't do this through display settings just that's what CompTIA generally states the first step would be.
But when they say "monitor" settings, are they referring to the settings on the monitor itself?
If the answer is in fact B, why is C displayed?
Sorry, but when you explain your answers, they're usually contradicting to what is being displayed.
This guy is a real jerkoff

In the IT world, knowing shortcuts can make you seem a bit more professional so sometimes CompTIA orients itself on those sort of commands. In the real world, FN function can be a pain and on old systems can trigger issues. While it's a cheap easy fix, it doesn't catch all the problems. It also doesn't neccesitate that a reboot will keep the same FN settings. For instance a laptop may switch us FN only to have powerpoint be configured poorly and when doing the slideshow you get terrible resolution issues, poor pairing, or more. I'd agree with display settings just being the more wise solution and testing afterwards with whatever needs to be used. Since this is a permanent setup too, restarting once to make sure the setting sticks will save an extra trip back to fix things :)

You cannot adjust the resolutions, select extend/mirror, change the position of screens with fn key I believe.
Fn key can only adjust brightness sort of things, isn't it?

discussion.content: So in the CompTIA books, it always states the FN key for laptop displays. Going to display settings is a more granular way to set up the display. Does Anyone else have thoughts on this?

I was stuck trying to figure out why this was not B and I realized the key word here is "end user". This is being worked on remotely. The technician can not press the function key remotely so the only choice they have is to go to adjust the monitor display settings
I will go for B because the Fn and function key (for instance F11 depending on your device I guess) will bring out the option to either project, extend, duplicate etc.

B. Use the Fn and function key combination: Many laptops have dedicated function keys (usually labeled with an icon representing a monitor or display) that can be used in combination with the Fn (Function) key to toggle or switch between different display modes. By pressing the appropriate Fn key along with the designated function key, the laptop can be configured to extend or duplicate the display onto the connected external monitor.

comments.content: if it means the monitor display settings located on the operating system and not the monitor itself*

discussion.content: this only makes sense if it means the monitor display settings located on the operating system and not the OS. if it means the actual monitor's display settings located on the monitor by pressing a button, then it would have to be FN key. Guessing it is referring to the OS, and thats some poor wording if so. should just be called "display settings"
Correct answer is B

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C.

Selected Answer: C
I agree with the answer C. The question is asking what the tech should CONFIGURE AFTER the cables are CONNECTED... he needs to configure the Display Settings
Exam Answer is B, Realworld Answer C
As a technician, we should go to display setting to configure main display, extended display and moving mouse from right to left or left to right . End user means remotely

C and B are both correct since I use the FN key.

This kind of questions should be banned since it displays 2 solutions with one possible answer.
An end-user wants to have a second monitor installed which means fix the display that's the first thing you'll do. Correct Answer Is C!
It's B because CompTIA manual refers to monitor settings as being the actual settings configured in the monitor, trough it's buttons. Check page 195.
the question basically says first time hook up. so the fn button is not the correct answer to the question. the 2nd monitor orientation needs set up first
FN Key to change ont the fly, but display settings to automatically the configuration once the monitor is plugged in.

Why should we adjust display settings in New Monitor if the question is about what to be configured in Laptop. 
So may be Fn keys is the answer.

I had this question in my exam, what do you think which domain this question refers to?

5.5?

questions.question_text: An end user wants to have a second monitor installed on a laptop. Which of the following would allow a technician to configure the laptop to show both screens once the cable is connected?

choices.B: Use the Fn and function key combination
choices.A: Plug an external monitor into the USB port.

discussion.content: After uninstalling the printer from a user's workstation and then reinstalling it, the printer is now working properly FOR THAT USER. The drivers will have to be updated for all workstations that are experiencing the issue.
If its Garbles texts then the problem is with the drivers

questions.question_text: A technician received a call that the network printer was printing garbled text. The technician printed a test page from several users' workstations and received the same result. The technician then ran a diagnostic on the printer, and everything passed. After uninstalling the printer from a user's workstation and then reinstalling it, the printer is now working properly. Which of the following was the cause of this issue?

choices.D: Drivers on the users' workstations were out of date.
choices.A: The font was changed by the user in the printing preferences.
choices.B: There were several print jobs hung in the queue.
choices.E: The print server spooler file was corrupt.
choices.C: The toner level in the printer was extremely low.
